items.standfirst: Israel's government approved Donald Trump's Gaza ceasefire and hostage release plan early on Friday.
items.content: Israel's government approved Donald Trump's Gaza ceasefire and hostage release plan early on Friday.

items.content: Israel’s government has approved “phase one” of the agreement, which will see captives exchanged and Israel withdraw.

items.standfirst: Israel's government has approved an agreement brokered by the US that paves the way for a ceasefire in the Gaza war and the return of all remaining hostages held by Hamas.
items.content: Israel's government has approved an agreement brokered by the US that paves the way for a ceasefire in the Gaza war and the return of all remaining hostages held by Hamas.

items.title: Israeli government approves hostage and ceasefire deal
items.standfirst: Trump says Hamas will likely release all Israeli hostages by early next week, as the "first phase" of a deal to end the war in Gaza is expected to take effect soon.
items.content: Trump says Hamas will likely release all Israeli hostages by early next week, as the "first phase" of a deal to end the war in Gaza is expected to take effect soon.

items.title: How the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal came together
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump had to maintain the trust of Israel and a series of Arab- and Muslim-majority nations. His ability to walk that tightrope was tested repeatedly.
items.content: President Donald Trump had to maintain the trust of Israel and a series of Arab- and Muslim-majority nations. His ability to walk that tightrope was tested repeatedly.

items.title: LIVE: Hamas gets guarantees of end to Gaza war, Israel approves ceasefire

items.content: Israel's government has approved the plan for the 'release of all captives' fighting in Gaza to stop within 24 hours.

items.title: Israel's government ratifies Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal
items.standfirst: Israel's government approved a ceasefire agreement with Hamas on Friday, setting the stage for the first phase of a deal, brokered under US President Donald Trump's peace initiative, to suspend hostilities in Gaza within 24 hours and secure the release of Israeli hostages within 72 hours.
items.content: Israel's government approved a ceasefire agreement with Hamas on Friday, setting the stage for the first phase of a deal, brokered under US President Donald Trump's peace initiative, to suspend hostilities in Gaza within 24 hours and secure the release of Israeli hostages within 72 hours.

items.title: Palestinians in Gaza’s south relearn sound of peace after truce deal
items.standfirst: The first phase of a Gaza ceasefire agreement has dramatically reduced Israeli attacks in southern Gaza.
items.content: The first phase of a Gaza ceasefire agreement has dramatically reduced Israeli attacks in southern Gaza.

items.title: Live: US to send 200 troops to 'oversee' Gaza ceasefire deal, reports say
items.standfirst: The Israeli government approved a ceasefire agreement for Gaza early Friday, nearly 24 hours after mediators announced the deal, which includes the release of Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. Meanwhile, senior US officials confirmed that a 200-member US military team will be deployed to the Middle East to help oversee a ceasefire implementation. Follow our liveblog for all the latest.
items.content: The Israeli government approved a ceasefire agreement for Gaza early Friday, nearly 24 hours after mediators announced the deal, which includes the release of Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. Meanwhile, senior US officials confirmed that a 200-member US military team will be deployed to the Middle East to help oversee a ceasefire implementation. Follow our liveblog for all the latest.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of Trump’s peace plan
items.standfirst: President Trump touted a landmark agreement to end the war in Gaza. Plus, two senior U.S. officials tell NBC News that 200 U.S. troops will be deployed to Israel, but not Gaza, to support an international security force. NBC News’ Garrett Haake reports.
items.content: President Trump touted a landmark agreement to end the war in Gaza. Plus, two senior U.S. officials tell NBC News that 200 U.S. troops will be deployed to Israel, but not Gaza, to support an international security force. NBC News’ Garrett Haake reports.

items.title: Israeli government approves Gaza hostage release deal

items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump pressed Israel's prime minister to agree to a ceasefire deal.
items.content: US President Donald Trump pressed Israel's prime minister to agree to a ceasefire deal.

items.title: Does Israel and Hamas signing the Gaza ceasefire deal mean the war is over?
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas signed an agreement on Thursday to cease fire and free Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in the first phase of US President Donald Trump's initiative to end the devastating two-year war in Gaza. The breakthrough has been met with joy and relief, but also caution for what this means in the long run.
items.content: Israel and Hamas signed an agreement on Thursday to cease fire and free Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in the first phase of US President Donald Trump's initiative to end the devastating two-year war in Gaza. The breakthrough has been met with joy and relief, but also caution for what this means in the long run.

items.title: After 2 years of brutal fighting, the Israel-Hamas war may be over
items.standfirst: A ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war could formally take effect today, and Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners could start going home as soon as this weekend.
items.content: A ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war could formally take effect today, and Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners could start going home as soon as this weekend.

items.title: Once the Gaza ceasefire goes into effect, what happens next? Here's what to know
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement for the "first phase" of a plan promoted by President Trump to end the war in Gaza. A ceasefire is expected to go into effect after an Israeli Cabinet vote.
items.content: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement for the "first phase" of a plan promoted by President Trump to end the war in Gaza. A ceasefire is expected to go into effect after an Israeli Cabinet vote.(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

items.title: Gaza ceasefire plan: how much credit does Trump deserve? – podcast

We’ve been here before, but is it different this time? Has Trump proved the doubters wrong?Jonathan Freedland speaks to Julian Borger about the prospect for peace in the Middle East and the US president’s role in getting to this pointArchive: PBS Newshour Continue reading...

items.title: REPLAY - Donald Trump says will 'try' to go to Egypt for Gaza deal signing

items.content: US President Donald Trump said on October 9 he would try to go to Egypt for the signing of a Gaza ceasefire and hostage release deal between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: Israeli government approves first part of peace deal to release hostages
items.standfirst: The previous ceasefire lasted from Jan. 19 to March 18, when Israel resumed military operations in Gaza.
items.content: The previous ceasefire lasted from Jan. 19 to March 18, when Israel resumed military operations in Gaza.

items.content: Palestinians celebrate on the streets of Khan Younis after the first phase of a Gaza peace deal was agreed.

items.title: Hostage families celebrate in Tel Aviv after Gaza breakthrough
items.standfirst: Relatives of Israeli hostages celebrated in Tel Aviv after the announcement that Israel and Hamas had signed the first phase of a peace deal.
items.content: Relatives of Israeli hostages celebrated in Tel Aviv after the announcement that Israel and Hamas had signed the first phase of a peace deal.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to truce and hostage release
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the "first phase" of a plan to end the war in Gaza, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday, with both parties also acknowledging that a deal had been reached."I am very proud to announce that Israel and Hamas have both signed off on the first Phase of our Peace Plan," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social
items.content: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the "first phase" of a plan to end the war in Gaza, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday, with both parties also acknowledging that a deal had been reached."I am very proud to announce that Israel and Hamas have both signed off on the first Phase of our Peace Plan," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social

ai_summary: Israel's government approved a ceasefire and hostage release plan brokered by the US.
The agreement involves exchanging captives and Israel withdrawing from certain areas.
Donald Trump plans to travel to Israel for the hostage release.
Hamas is expected to release all Israeli hostages by early next week.
The first phase of the deal is expected to take effect soon.

clusters.title: Letitia James is the latest target of Donald Trump’s revenge agenda

items.content: Federal prosecutors have indicted New York’s attorney-general

items.title: 10/9: CBS Evening News Plus
items.standfirst: Breaking down indictment against New York Attorney General Letitia James; Reporter's Notebook: Will China return to buying American soybeans?
items.content: Breaking down indictment against New York Attorney General Letitia James; Reporter's Notebook: Will China return to buying American soybeans?

items.title: Why was New York Attorney General Letitia James indicted?
items.standfirst: The indictment accuses James on two felony counts: bank fraud and making false statements to a financial institution.
items.content: The indictment accuses James on two felony counts: bank fraud and making false statements to a financial institution.

items.title: New York AG Letitia James indicted in Virginia
items.standfirst: A federal grand jury has indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James, marking the second Trump foe to face federal prosecution in recent weeks.
items.content: A federal grand jury has indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James, marking the second Trump foe to face federal prosecution in recent weeks.

items.title: New York Attorney General Letitia James criminally indicted
items.standfirst: James, who led a civil fraud case against US President Donald Trump, was indicted in Alexandria, Virginia.
items.content: James, who led a civil fraud case against US President Donald Trump, was indicted in Alexandria, Virginia.

items.title: 10/9: The Daily Report

items.content: Kelly O'Grady reports on the indictment of New York Attorney General Letitia James, and the status of a hostage release deal in the Middle East.

items.title: NY Attorney General Letitia James, a prominent Trump critic, criminally indicted
items.standfirst: New York Attorney General Letitia James — who led the civil fraud case that won a nearly half-billion-dollar judgment against Donald Trump — was indicted Thursday on federal bank fraud charges, becoming the second high-profile Trump critic to face prosecution in as many days.
items.content: New York Attorney General Letitia James — who led the civil fraud case that won a nearly half-billion-dollar judgment against Donald Trump — was indicted Thursday on federal bank fraud charges, becoming the second high-profile Trump critic to face prosecution in as many days.

items.title: What do prosecutors have to prove in the Letitia James case?
items.standfirst: A federal grand jury on Thursday indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James on two charges. CBS News legal contributor Jessica Levinson joins with analysis.
items.content: A federal grand jury on Thursday indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James on two charges. CBS News legal contributor Jessica Levinson joins with analysis.

items.title: 10/9: The Takeout with Major Garrett
items.standfirst: New York Attorney General Letitia James is indicted; The government shutdown is now in its ninth day with no sign of a deal.
items.content: New York Attorney General Letitia James is indicted; The government shutdown is now in its ninth day with no sign of a deal.

items.title: Reporter's Notebook: Will China return to buying American soybeans?
items.standfirst: For the first time on record, Chinese buyers ordered zero soybeans from U.S. farmers as the fall harvest began. Farmers hurt by President Trump's tariff policies are left wondering, what if these buyers don't come back? "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.
items.content: For the first time on record, Chinese buyers ordered zero soybeans from U.S. farmers as the fall harvest began. Farmers hurt by President Trump's tariff policies are left wondering, what if these buyers don't come back? "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.

items.title: Read the full Letitia James indictment
items.standfirst: A federal grand jury in Virginia indicted Letitia James on one count of bank fraud and another of making false statements to a financial institution.
items.content: A federal grand jury in Virginia indicted Letitia James on one count of bank fraud and another of making false statements to a financial institution.

items.title: NY attorney-general Letitia James indicted after pressure from Trump
items.standfirst: Case comes after president urged Department of Justice to take legal action against top prosecutor
items.content: Case comes after president urged Department of Justice to take legal action against top prosecutor

items.title: NY Attorney General Letitia James indicted on fraud charges: Reports
items.standfirst: James had been a target of US President Trump since successfully suing him for overstating his wealth to dupe lenders.
items.content: James had been a target of US President Trump since successfully suing him for overstating his wealth to dupe lenders.

items.title: Justice Department indicts Letitia James after pressure from Trump
items.standfirst: The indictment comes after steady pressure from President Trump to prosecute James, who successfully sued Trump and his company for inflating the value of some of its properties.
items.content: The indictment comes after steady pressure from President Trump to prosecute James, who successfully sued Trump and his company for inflating the value of some of its properties.(Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

ai_summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James was indicted on federal charges.
The indictment occurred in Alexandria, Virginia, on bank fraud charges.
James led a civil fraud case against Donald Trump.
This is the second Trump critic to face federal prosecution recently.
Prosecutors must prove the charges against James in court.

clusters.title: Peru's deeply unpopular president impeached over crime wave
clusters.neutral_headline: Peru President Dina Boluarte Impeached Amidst Crime Wave

items.title: Peru's deeply unpopular president impeached over crime wave
items.standfirst: Peru's Congress voted early Friday to remove deeply unpopular President Dina Boluarte from office as a crime wave grips the South American nation.
items.content: Peru's Congress voted early Friday to remove deeply unpopular President Dina Boluarte from office as a crime wave grips the South American nation.

items.title: Peru lawmakers vote to oust president Dina Boluarte over crime crisis
items.standfirst: Congress leader José Jerí sworn in as interim president as majority of lawmakers initiate impeachment against BoluarteLawmakers in Peru have voted to remove the president, Dina Boluarte, whose term has been marked by protests and accusations of failing to stem crime.Boluarte refused to appear before Congress on Friday for an overnight hearing after a majority of lawmakers, including some once loyal to her, voted to initiate impeachment proceedings. Continue reading...
items.content: Congress leader José Jerí sworn in as interim president as majority of lawmakers initiate impeachment against BoluarteLawmakers in Peru have voted to remove the president, Dina Boluarte, whose term has been marked by protests and accusations of failing to stem crime.Boluarte refused to appear before Congress on Friday for an overnight hearing after a majority of lawmakers, including some once loyal to her, voted to initiate impeachment proceedings. Continue reading...

items.title: Peruvian lawmakers vote to impeach President Boluarte
items.standfirst: The Peruvian Congress voted in favor of removing the country's President Dina Boluarte from office on Friday, after debating and approving motions declaring her "permanently morally unfit."Lawmakers s...
items.content: The Peruvian Congress voted in favor of removing the country's President Dina Boluarte from office on Friday, after debating and approving motions declaring her "permanently morally unfit."Lawmakers s...

items.title: Peru's Congress votes to impeach Dina Boluarte as crime wave stirs anger
items.standfirst: Lawmakers in Peru voted on Friday to impeach the country's unpopular president Dina Boluarte and replace her with Congress chief Jose Jeri. Boluarte, who refused to attend the overnight hearing, has been criticised for failing to stem mounting crime in the South American country.
items.content: Lawmakers in Peru voted on Friday to impeach the country's unpopular president Dina Boluarte and replace her with Congress chief Jose Jeri. Boluarte, who refused to attend the overnight hearing, has been criticised for failing to stem mounting crime in the South American country.

items.title: Peru’s Congress votes to remove President Boluarte as crime grips nation
items.standfirst: Unlike eight previous attempts to remove the president, almost all legislative factions expressed support for the move.
items.content: Unlike eight previous attempts to remove the president, almost all legislative factions expressed support for the move.

items.title: Peru's Congress removes President Boluarte as a crime wave grips the country
items.standfirst: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to swiftly remove Peru's first female president shortly after midnight, marking yet another leadership shake-up in a nation rocked by violence and political turmoil.
items.content: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to swiftly remove Peru's first female president shortly after midnight, marking yet another leadership shake-up in a nation rocked by violence and political turmoil.(Image credit: Richard Drew)

ai_summary: Peru's Congress voted to remove President Dina Boluarte from office.
The impeachment followed a vote declaring her "permanently morally unfit."
Boluarte was criticized for failing to address a rising crime wave.
Congress chief Jose Jeri was sworn in as interim president.
Almost all legislative factions supported the impeachment.

clusters.title: Powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake strikes off coast of Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Earthquake Strikes Philippines, Tsunami Warnings Issued

items.title: Powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake strikes off coast of Philippines
items.standfirst: The 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of the southern Philippines island of Mindanao and prompted a tsunami warning.
items.content: The 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of the southern Philippines island of Mindanao and prompted a tsunami warning.

items.title: Strong 7.4 magnitude quake hits southern Philippines
items.standfirst: One person has died from Friday's earthquake, which comes a week after a deadly quake hit the island of Cebu.
items.content: One person has died from Friday's earthquake, which comes a week after a deadly quake hit the island of Cebu.

items.title: Tsunami threat lifted after Philippine earthquake – as it happened
items.standfirst: Reports of panic and damaged buildings as strong quake hits PhilippinesFull report: prayers as strong shaking hits the PhilippinesPhilippines president directs agencies to aid evacuations and provide help to ‘everyone who needs it’Ferdinand Marcos, the president of the Philippines, said the government was working “round the clock” to ensure help reaches “everyone who needs it”.We are now assessing the situation on the ground and ensuring that everyone is safe. … Search, rescue, and relief operations are already being prepared and will be deployed as soon as it is safe to do so.Let us continue to look out for one another and pray for the safety of all our countrymen. Continue reading...
items.content: Reports of panic and damaged buildings as strong quake hits PhilippinesFull report: prayers as strong shaking hits the PhilippinesPhilippines president directs agencies to aid evacuations and provide help to ‘everyone who needs it’Ferdinand Marcos, the president of the Philippines, said the government was working “round the clock” to ensure help reaches “everyone who needs it”.We are now assessing the situation on the ground and ensuring that everyone is safe. … Search, rescue, and relief operations are already being prepared and will be deployed as soon as it is safe to do so.Let us continue to look out for one another and pray for the safety of all our countrymen. Continue reading...

items.title: Powerful 7.4 magnitude earthquake strikes off southern Philippines, tsunami warnings issued
Philippines rocked by damaging 7.6-magnitude earthquake
items.standfirst: Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr. said authorities were assessing the situation on the ground and search and rescue efforts were being preparedThe southern Philippines was rocked by a powerful 7.6-magnitude earthquake that struck in the region of Mindanao on Friday, initially triggering a tsunami warning that was later lifted.The Philippine seismology agency issued a tsunami warning, saying hazardous tsunami waves were possible for coasts located within 300km (186 miles) of the earthquake’s epicentre. Hours later the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said the tsunami threat had passed. Continue reading...
items.content: Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr. said authorities were assessing the situation on the ground and search and rescue efforts were being preparedThe southern Philippines was rocked by a powerful 7.6-magnitude earthquake that struck in the region of Mindanao on Friday, initially triggering a tsunami warning that was later lifted.The Philippine seismology agency issued a tsunami warning, saying hazardous tsunami waves were possible for coasts located within 300km (186 miles) of the earthquake’s epicentre. Hours later the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said the tsunami threat had passed. Continue reading...

items.title: Tsunami warnings issued after earthquake in the Philippines
items.standfirst: Tsunami warnings were issued for several countries after a 7.4 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of the southern Philippines.
items.content: Tsunami warnings were issued for several countries after a 7.4 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of the southern Philippines.

ai_summary: A 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of the Philippines.
A tsunami warning was issued following the earthquake.
One person died from the earthquake.
The Philippine president directed agencies to aid evacuations.
The tsunami threat was later lifted.

clusters.title: Major Russian strikes cut power across Kyiv
clusters.neutral_headline: Major Russian Strikes Cut Power Across Kyiv

items.title: Major Russian strikes cut power across Kyiv
items.standfirst: Drone and missile strikes caused blackouts in Kyiv and killed a seven-year-old in Ukraine's south-east, officials say.
items.content: Drone and missile strikes caused blackouts in Kyiv and killed a seven-year-old in Ukraine's south-east, officials say.

items.title: Gold Slips Below $4,000, WTI, Brent Crude Prices Fall As Russia Escalates Attacks On Ukraine's Energy Infrastructure
items.standfirst: Gold prices tumbled below the $4,000-per-ounce mark on Friday, and crude prices fell as Russia escalated strikes on Ukraine’s energy grid, heightening geopolitical tensions. Russia Attacks Ukraine’s Energy Infrastructure The pullback comes amid fresh reports of a “massive” Russian assault on…
items.content: Gold prices tumbled below the $4,000-per-ounce mark on Friday, and crude prices fell as Russia escalated strikes on Ukraine’s energy grid, heightening geopolitical tensions. Russia Attacks Ukraine’s Energy Infrastructure The pullback comes amid fresh reports of a “massive” Russian assault on…

items.title: ‘Massive’ Russian attack on Ukraine capital triggers blackouts and sets high-rise alight
items.standfirst: Powerful blasts reported in Kyiv as missiles and drones target energy infrastructure, injuring nineThe Ukrainian capital was plunged into darkness early on Friday by what the air force called a “massive attack”, as Russia pummelled Kyiv’s infrastructure, cutting off water and energy supplies and triggering a fire in a high-rise apartment building.Kyiv’s mayor said Russian forces had targeted “critical infrastructure” and nine people had been injured, with five of them taken to hospital. Vitali Klitschko also said power cuts and disruptions to the water supply had hit districts on the east bank of the Dnipro River that runs through the city. Continue reading...
items.content: Powerful blasts reported in Kyiv as missiles and drones target energy infrastructure, injuring nineThe Ukrainian capital was plunged into darkness early on Friday by what the air force called a “massive attack”, as Russia pummelled Kyiv’s infrastructure, cutting off water and energy supplies and triggering a fire in a high-rise apartment building.Kyiv’s mayor said Russian forces had targeted “critical infrastructure” and nine people had been injured, with five of them taken to hospital. Vitali Klitschko also said power cuts and disruptions to the water supply had hit districts on the east bank of the Dnipro River that runs through the city. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘Massive’ Russian missile and drone attack sparks power cuts in Kyiv
items.standfirst: Ukraine reported a large-scale Russian assault on Kyiv early Friday, involving ballistic missiles and drone strikes that caused widespread power outages and injured at least nine people. The attack, which targeted critical infrastructure, is part of what officials say is an intensified Russian campaign against Ukraine’s energy grid.
items.content: Ukraine reported a large-scale Russian assault on Kyiv early Friday, involving ballistic missiles and drone strikes that caused widespread power outages and injured at least nine people. The attack, which targeted critical infrastructure, is part of what officials say is an intensified Russian campaign against Ukraine’s energy grid.

ai_summary: Russian strikes caused blackouts in Kyiv.
Drone and missile strikes targeted energy infrastructure.
At least nine people were injured in the attacks.
The attacks are part of an intensified campaign against Ukraine's energy grid.
A seven-year-old was killed in Ukraine's south-east.

clusters.title: Belgian police arrest three for plotting drone attack on prime minister
clusters.neutral_headline: Belgium Arrests Three for Alleged Drone Attack Plot

items.title: Belgian police arrest three for plotting drone attack on prime minister
items.standfirst: Evidence was found in a building a few hundred metres from Prime Minister Bart De Wever's Antwerp residence.
items.content: Evidence was found in a building a few hundred metres from Prime Minister Bart De Wever's Antwerp residence.

items.title: Belgium says it foiled suspected drone plot to attack prime minister
items.standfirst: Belgian authorities arrested three men in Antwerp on Thursday over a suspected jihadist plot to attack Prime Minister Bart De Wever using drone-mounted explosives. Investigators found bomb-making materials and a 3D printer at their homes. Officials say the arrests likely prevented a major terrorist act.
items.content: Belgian authorities arrested three men in Antwerp on Thursday over a suspected jihadist plot to attack Prime Minister Bart De Wever using drone-mounted explosives. Investigators found bomb-making materials and a 3D printer at their homes. Officials say the arrests likely prevented a major terrorist act.

items.title: Police thwart suspected plot to attack Belgium's prime minister
items.standfirst: Three men have been arrested in Belgium over a suspected plot to attack the country's politicians, including Prime Minister Bart De Wever.
items.content: Three men have been arrested in Belgium over a suspected plot to attack the country's politicians, including Prime Minister Bart De Wever.

items.title: Belgian PM reported to be among targets of ‘jihad-inspired’ drone plot
items.standfirst: Officers in Antwerp arrest three suspects and recover an improvised explosive device Police in Belgium have arrested three young adults suspected of plotting a jihadist-inspired attack using drone-mounted explosives, with the Belgian prime minister reported to be among the politicians targeted.The arrests were made in the northern city of Antwerp as part of an investigation into “attempted terrorist murder and participation in the activities of a terrorist group”, the federal prosecutor Ann Fransen told a news conference. Continue reading...
items.content: Officers in Antwerp arrest three suspects and recover an improvised explosive device Police in Belgium have arrested three young adults suspected of plotting a jihadist-inspired attack using drone-mounted explosives, with the Belgian prime minister reported to be among the politicians targeted.The arrests were made in the northern city of Antwerp as part of an investigation into “attempted terrorist murder and participation in the activities of a terrorist group”, the federal prosecutor Ann Fransen told a news conference. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Belgian police arrested three men in Antwerp.
The arrests were related to a suspected drone attack plot.
The plot targeted Prime Minister Bart De Wever.
Investigators found bomb-making materials and a 3D printer.
Authorities believe the arrests prevented a major terrorist act.

clusters.title: Chicago federal judge temporarily blocks National Guard deployment in Illinois
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Blocks National Guard Deployment in Illinois

items.title: Chicago federal judge temporarily blocks National Guard deployment in Illinois
items.standfirst: A federal judge on Thursday granted a partial restraining order to block the Trump administration's deployment of National Guard troops in Illinois, after state and local leaders objected to the deployment.
items.content: A federal judge on Thursday granted a partial restraining order to block the Trump administration's deployment of National Guard troops in Illinois, after state and local leaders objected to the deployment.

items.title: Hundreds of Texas National Guard troops arrive in Chicago as judge temporarily blocks deployment
items.standfirst: Separate courtrooms heard arguments over President Trump's efforts to deploy National Guard troops to U.S. cities on Thursday. A federal judge in Chicago issued a temporary block on deployments in the city where the Trump administration claims troops are needed to address violent protests. CBS News correspondent Ian Lee reports.
items.content: Separate courtrooms heard arguments over President Trump's efforts to deploy National Guard troops to U.S. cities on Thursday. A federal judge in Chicago issued a temporary block on deployments in the city where the Trump administration claims troops are needed to address violent protests. CBS News correspondent Ian Lee reports.

items.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump’s effort to deploy national guard in Chicago
items.standfirst: Much-anticipated judgment centers on efforts by Trump administration to use troops to aid immigration crackdownA judge has temporarily blocked the Trump administration from federalizing or deploying the national guard in Illinois after Donald Trump ordered hundreds of troops to Chicago to help with immigration enforcement and to battle what the White House says are high crime rates in the city.US district judge April Perry issued her decision from the bench after more than two hours of arguments from lawyers for the federal government and the state of Illinois, which sued the Trump administration over the deployment. The order took effect on Thursday and will remain in place for two weeks. Continue reading...
items.content: Much-anticipated judgment centers on efforts by Trump administration to use troops to aid immigration crackdownA judge has temporarily blocked the Trump administration from federalizing or deploying the national guard in Illinois after Donald Trump ordered hundreds of troops to Chicago to help with immigration enforcement and to battle what the White House says are high crime rates in the city.US district judge April Perry issued her decision from the bench after more than two hours of arguments from lawyers for the federal government and the state of Illinois, which sued the Trump administration over the deployment. The order took effect on Thursday and will remain in place for two weeks. Continue reading...

items.title: Hundreds of US National Guard troops arrive in Chicago
items.standfirst: Troops from Texas have been sent on a controversial mission to support President Trump's immigration crackdown.
items.content: Troops from Texas have been sent on a controversial mission to support President Trump's immigration crackdown.

ai_summary: A judge temporarily blocked the deployment of National Guard troops in Illinois.
The order was in response to the Trump administration's plans.
The deployment was intended to address violent protests.
Hundreds of Texas National Guard troops had already arrived in Chicago.
The order will remain in place for two weeks.

clusters.title: Man who appealed Pelicot rape conviction handed longer jail term
clusters.neutral_headline: French Court Increases Sentence for Pelicot Rapist

items.title: Man who appealed Pelicot rape conviction handed longer jail term
items.standfirst: A French court increases by a year the jail term of the only man who challenged his conviction for raping Gisèle Pelicot.
items.content: A French court increases by a year the jail term of the only man who challenged his conviction for raping Gisèle Pelicot.

items.title: Only man to appeal Gisele Pelicot rape conviction handed longer sentence
items.standfirst: A French appeals court has handed a longer 10-year sentence to the only man to challenge his conviction for raping Gisele Pelicot while she was drugged and unconscious.
items.content: A French appeals court has handed a longer 10-year sentence to the only man to challenge his conviction for raping Gisele Pelicot while she was drugged and unconscious.

items.title: French appeal court increases sentence of Gisèle Pelicot rapist
items.standfirst: Husamettin Dogan loses appeal after jury at retrial finds him guilty of raping Pelicot while she was sedatedA man has been found guilty on appeal of raping Gisèle Pelicot after she was drugged unconscious by her husband – and has had his prison sentence increased to 10 years.Husamettin Dogan, 44, an unemployed builder, who had contested his first conviction last year, faced a retrial this week at Nîmes court of appeal. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: A French court increased the jail term of a man convicted of rape.
The man appealed his conviction for raping Gisèle Pelicot.
The sentence was increased to 10 years.
The rape occurred while Pelicot was drugged and unconscious.
The man was found guilty on appeal.

items.title: Macron summons party leaders ahead of Friday deadline to appoint new French PM
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Emmanuel Macron is expected to name his sixth prime minister in two years on Friday evening as he attempts to break the country's political deadlock and avert another snap election. The embattled centrist president has summoned the leaders of all mainstream parties to the Élysée presidential palace prior to the announcement.

The embattled centrist president has summoned the leaders of all mainstream parties to the Élysée presidential palace prior to the announcement.

clusters.title: Candidates in Virginia governor's debate clash over shutdown and violent rhetoric
clusters.neutral_headline: Candidates Clash in Virginia Governor Debate

items.title: Candidates in Virginia governor's debate clash over shutdown and violent rhetoric
items.standfirst: Republican Winsome Earle-Sears and Democrat Abigail Spanberger have faced off on the debate stage in Virginia's high-stakes governor's race.
items.content: Republican Winsome Earle-Sears and Democrat Abigail Spanberger have faced off on the debate stage in Virginia's high-stakes governor's race.

items.title: Spanberger and Earle-Sears tussle over violent political rhetoric in only debate
items.standfirst: The Republican pressed Spanberger on a 2022 text message sent by the Democratic candidate for Virginia attorney general.
items.content: Democrat Abigail Spanberger passed on a chance to use one of the most high-profile moments of her run for Virginia governor to withdraw her endorsement for her party’s attorney general nominee for his use of violent rhetoric in a text message. The subject of Jay Jones’ violent message from three years ago emerged immediately as the Democrat faced Republican Winsome Earle-Sears on Thursday in the only planned debate of the closely watched race. Spanberger condemned the text as “abhorrent” but repeatedly declined to say whether she would withdraw her support for Jones, saying it should be left to the voters in the Nov. 4 election. “The voters now have the information, and it is up to voters to make an individual choice based on this information,” she said. Jones suggested the former Republican House speaker should get “two bullets to the head.” He has apologized for the text, which became public last week amid rising fears of political violence following a string of incidents, including the killing of Charlie Kirk on Sept. 10 and the attack on Minnesota lawmakers in June. Jones' text dominated the early portion of the debate at Norfolk State University that otherwise include feisty exchanges on public policy and culture war issues. Earle-Sears pivoted from the first question, about Virginia’s car tax, to insist that Spanberger address the issue. “My opponent needs to answer about Jay Jones.” The lieutenant governor then repeatedly turned to ask Spanberger what it would take for her to call for Jones to leave the race. “You have little girls,” she said, looking directly at her opponent and ignoring moderators’ attempts to allow the Democratic nominee to answer. “What would it take? Him pulling the trigger? Is that what would do it and then you would say he needs to get out of the race, Abigail?” While Spanberger declined to say whether she would continue to support Jones, she made it clear she disagreed with his text. "I denounced them when I learned of them and I will denounce them at every opportunity," she said. The debate frequently bogged down with cross-talk and by Earle-Sears' interruptions of her opponent. Their differences centered around whose party deserves blame for the government shutdown, immigration enforcement, abortion rights and gay marriage — which the lieutenant governor opposes. Virginia is one of two states electing governors in November and is often viewed as a bellwether election for the party occupying the White House. Democrats were hoping for decisive wins in Virginia to use as a springboard into next year’s midterms, but have encountered some turbulence as Republicans have announced a combined $3 million ad push in recent days to keep the text messaging saga top of mind for voters in the campaign’s final stretch. President Donald Trump looms large in the Virginia gubernatorial contest. He’s not only unpopular with Democrats and Independents, his administration’s gutting of the federal government through DOGE cuts and his push to deny backpay to federal workers still on the payroll but forced off the job during the partial federal government shutdown disproportionately impact Virginia voters. There was little talk about the history at stake during the hour-long debate. Either would be the first female governor of Virginia and Earle-Sears would be the first Black woman to lead the state.

ai_summary: Candidates in Virginia's governor's race debated.
The debate focused on the government shutdown and violent rhetoric.
Republican Winsome Earle-Sears and Democrat Abigail Spanberger participated.
They discussed a 2022 text message sent by Spanberger.
The debate was part of a high-stakes governor's race.

clusters.title: US buys Argentinian pesos, finalises $20bn currency swap, says US Treasury
clusters.neutral_headline: US Buys Argentine Pesos, Finalizes Currency Swap

items.title: US buys Argentinian pesos, finalises $20bn currency swap, says US Treasury
items.standfirst: Argentina's right-wing President Milei, a close ally of President Trump, faces a critical midterm election this month.
items.content: Argentina's right-wing President Milei, a close ally of President Trump, faces a critical midterm election this month.

items.title: US buys Argentine pesos, finalises $20 billion currency swap framework
items.standfirst: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Thursday that the United States has bought Argentine pesos and finalised a $20 billion economic support program with the South American nation's central bank, after concluding talks with his counterpart.The support comes as Argentina's right-wing President Javier Milei, a close ally of US President Donald Trump, had been struggling with market turbulence after a defeat in Buenos Aires provincial elections seen as a bellwether for upcoming mid-terms.
items.content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Thursday that the United States has bought Argentine pesos and finalised a $20 billion economic support program with the South American nation's central bank, after concluding talks with his counterpart.The support comes as Argentina's right-wing President Javier Milei, a close ally of US President Donald Trump, had been struggling with market turbulence after a defeat in Buenos Aires provincial elections seen as a bellwether for upcoming mid-terms.

items.title: Trump boosts Argentina's Milei with $20 bn economic lifeline as US buys pesos
items.standfirst: The US has stepped in to bolster Argentina's floundering economy, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent on Thursday announcing a $20 billion economic support package and the purchase of Argentine pesos aimed at stabilising the South American nation’s volatile markets. Argentine President Javier Milei, a staunch ally of Donald Trump, hailed the US president's "vision and powerful leadership" for the deal.
items.content: The US has stepped in to bolster Argentina's floundering economy, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent on Thursday announcing a $20 billion economic support package and the purchase of Argentine pesos aimed at stabilising the South American nation’s volatile markets. Argentine President Javier Milei, a staunch ally of Donald Trump, hailed the US president's "vision and powerful leadership" for the deal.

ai_summary: The US bought Argentine pesos.
The US finalized a $20 billion currency swap framework.
Argentina's right-wing President Milei is a close ally of Donald Trump.
The support comes as Argentina struggles with market turbulence.
The US Treasury Secretary announced the deal.

clusters.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
clusters.neutral_headline: ID photos of 70,000 users may have been leaked, Discord says

items.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
items.standfirst: As more sites require IDs for user age verification, expect more such breaches to come.
items.content: Discord says that hackers made off with images of 70,000 users’ government IDs that they were required to provide in order to use the site. Like an increasing number of sites, Discord requires certain users to provide a photo or scan of their driver's license or other government ID that shows they meet the minimum age requirements in their country. In some cases, Discord allows users to prove their age by providing a selfie that shows their faces (it’s not clear how a face proves someone’s age, but there you go). The social media site imposes these requirements on users who are reported by other users to be under the minimum age for the country they’re connecting from. “A substantial risk for identity theft” On Wednesday, Discord said that ID images of roughly 70,000 users “may have had government-ID photos exposed” in a recent breach of a third-party service Discord entrusted to manage the data. The affected users had communicated with Discord’s Customer Support or Trust & Safety teams and subsequently submitted the IDs in reviews of age-related appeals.Read full article Comments

items.title: ID photos of 70,000 users may have been leaked, Discord says
items.standfirst: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
items.content: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
